conversations.content: How do the tax costs affect Berkshire's performance compared to the S&P 500 in different market conditions?

Well, it's quite simple really. When the S&P 500 has a positive return, our after-tax numbers would lag behind because we have to pay taxes on those gains. On the other hand, in years when the S&P 500 has a negative return, our after-tax numbers would actually look better because we don't have to pay taxes on losses. Over time, though, those tax costs add up and cause a substantial lag in our performance compared to the S&P 500.
What was the impact of the housing-related issues on our operating businesses last year?

The housing-related issues did cause some setbacks for a few of our businesses, like brick, carpet, and real estate brokerage operations. But I'd call these setbacks minor and temporary. The good news is that our competitive position in these businesses remains strong, and we have top-notch CEOs running them. So, I'm not too worried about these businesses in the long run.
What was the compounded annual gain in per-share investments for the entire 42-year period you're discussing?
For the entire 42 years, our compounded annual gain in per-share investments was 27.1%. That's a pretty impressive number, but I have to caution that it's not a guarantee of future performance.
You mention that Berkshire's past record can't be duplicated or even approached. Why is that?

Well, it's simple: our base of assets and earnings is now far too large for us to make those outsized gains we saw in the past. It's like trying to get a big ship to turn on a dime - it's just not going to happen. We'll do our best to make sure the future is not disappointing, but we can't come close to duplicating the past.
What are the key criteria you and Charlie look for when evaluating companies for potential purchase?

We look for four main things: a business we understand, favorable long-term economics, able and trustworthy management, and a sensible price tag. It's like checking off the boxes on a to-do list - if a company can tick all those boxes, we're interested.
What do you mean by a 'moat' in the context of a business, and why is it important for a company's long-term success?

A 'moat' is a barrier that protects a company's excellent returns on invested capital. Think of it like a castle - if you're earning high returns, competitors will try to storm the castle and take a piece of the action. A moat can be something like being the low-cost producer or having a powerful brand. It's essential because it helps a company sustain its success over time, rather than being a flash in the pan like those 'Roman Candles' I mentioned.
What kind of companies do you tend to rule out based on your investment criteria?

I rule out companies in industries that are prone to rapid and continuous change. You see, a moat that needs to be constantly rebuilt isn't much of a moat at all. It's like trying to hold water in your hands - it just won't work.
Can a business with a great manager still be considered a great business?

No, not if its success depends solely on that manager. A terrific CEO is a huge asset, don't get me wrong, but if the business requires a superstar to produce great results, then the business itself isn't great. I mean, think of a medical partnership led by a top brain surgeon - when the surgeon leaves, the partnership's advantage goes with them.
What was the pre-tax return on invested capital when Berkshire first bought See's, and what factors contributed to minimizing the funds required for operations?

When we first bought See's, the pre-tax return on invested capital was 60%. Two key factors helped keep the funds required for operations low: first, the product was sold for cash, which eliminated accounts receivable; and second, the production and distribution cycle was short, minimizing inventories. It's a great example of how a well-designed business can generate a lot of cash without needing a lot of capital.
How has See's performed since Berkshire's acquisition in terms of sales and pre-tax profits, and what has happened to the capital required to run the business?

See's has done fantastically well since we acquired it. Sales have grown from $30 million to $383 million, and pre-tax profits have jumped from less than $5 million to $82 million. Meanwhile, the capital required to run the business has increased from $8 million to $40 million. But here's the remarkable part: we've only had to reinvest $32 million of See's profits since 1972 to achieve this growth. The rest, $1.35 billion in pre-tax earnings, has been available for us to invest in other opportunities.
What makes a company like See's Candies unusual in terms of its growth and capital requirements?

Well, See's is unusual because it can grow its earnings significantly without needing a proportional amount of capital investment. Typically, companies need to invest a lot of money to finance their growth, but See's has been able to increase its earnings from $5 million to $82 million without requiring a huge amount of capital.
Can you give an example of a company that has good business economics but still requires significant reinvestment of earnings to grow?

Our own FlightSafety is a good example of this. It's a terrific business that delivers huge benefits to its customers and has a durable competitive advantage, but it still needs to reinvest a significant amount of its earnings to grow. Since we purchased it in 1996, we've had to reinvest heavily to keep it going, with depreciation charges totaling $923 million.
What was the outcome of your investment in U.S. Air preferred stock in 1989?

Well, I'd say it was a bit of a rollercoaster. Initially, it seemed like a bad idea - the company went into a tailspin soon after our investment, and our preferred dividend was no longer being paid. But we got lucky, and during one of those bursts of optimism for airlines, we were able to sell our shares in 1998 for a hefty gain. Of course, that gain was just luck, as the company went bankrupt not once, but twice, in the decade following our sale.
You describe three types of 'savings accounts' in terms of their interest rates and requirements for additional deposits. Which one does the airline industry resemble?

The airline industry is a perfect example of the 'gruesome account'. It pays an inadequate interest rate, and to make matters worse, it requires you to keep adding money at those disappointing returns. It's a bottomless pit, and investors have been pouring money into it for years, despite the lack of promising returns.
What was the purchase price you were willing to pay for See's, and what was the seller's initial asking price?
I was adamant about not going above $25 million for See's, while the seller was initially asking for $30 million. Fortunately, the seller caved, and I got a great deal.
How much did the Dallas-Fort Worth NBC station earn in pre-tax income in 2006, and what is its estimated capital value today?

In 2006, the station earned $73 million pre-tax. As for its capital value, it's estimated to be around $800 million today. I have to say, passing on that deal still hurts - it's a great example of an unforced error on my part.
What qualities do you look for in a manager, and how did Susan demonstrate these qualities to become CEO of Borsheims?

I look for brains, passion, and integrity in a manager. Susan demonstrated these qualities by being smart, loving the business, and loving her associates. She didn't have a traditional managerial background, but those qualities are far more important to me than an MBA degree.
What was the significance of Iscar opening a plant in Dalian, China, and how did it impact their operations?

Iscar opening a plant in Dalian, China was significant because it allowed them to move their brains - their expertise and knowledge - closer to the raw material, tungsten, which is mined in China. Instead of shipping tungsten to Israel, they can now process it locally, making their operations more efficient.
How do you evaluate the performance of your investments, such as American Express, Coca-Cola, and Procter & Gamble?

I evaluate their performance in two ways. First, I look at the improvement in their earnings, taking into account the conditions of their industry. Second, I consider whether their competitive advantages, or 'moats,' have widened over the year. It's not about what their market prices do in a given year, but about the fundamental strengths of the businesses themselves.
What was the earnings performance like for your four largest holdings in 2007?

In 2007, three of our four largest holdings - American Express, Coca-Cola, and Procter & Gamble - increased their per-share earnings by 12%, 14%, and 14%, respectively. The fourth, Wells Fargo, had a small decline in earnings due to the real estate bubble bursting, but I believe its intrinsic value still increased, even if only slightly.
How do the accounting rules for your derivative contracts differ from those for your investment portfolio?

The accounting rules differ in that changes in the value of our derivative contracts must be applied each quarter to earnings, whereas changes in value for our investment portfolio only affect earnings if we sell or write down a holding. It's a bit like the difference between getting a daily report card versus one at the end of the semester - one gives you a lot of ups and downs, while the other gives you a more stable view of how you're doing.
Will the large swings in reported earnings from your derivative positions bother you and Charlie Munger?

Not at all. We're focused on the long game, and we're willing to trade some short-term volatility in earnings for greater gains in net worth down the line. As we've seen in our catastrophe insurance business, it's a trade-off we're comfortable making.
How do you and your partner plan to approach the potential $1 billion or more swings in a quarter?

My partner and I won't be losing sleep over these swings. We're willing to trade short-term earnings volatility for long-term gains in net worth, just like in our catastrophe insurance business. It's a philosophy that serves us well in derivatives too.
Has the weakening of the U.S. dollar against major currencies helped reduce the U.S. trade deficit?

Well, the theory is that a falling currency should cure a trade deficit by making our products cheaper for foreigners and their products more expensive for us. And while the large drop in the dollar has undoubtedly tempered our deficit, the numbers don't entirely bear that out. For example, our trade deficits with Germany and Canada actually rose between 2002 and 2007, despite the dollar's decline.
Why do you believe America will continue to produce growing prosperity for its citizens?

I believe America's prosperity will continue because of its strong foundation - the rule of law, a market-responsive economic system, and a belief in meritocracy. These elements create an environment where people can thrive and innovate, and that's a recipe for success.
What is the current status of Berkshire's succession plan for the investment job?

We've made good progress on that front. We've identified four strong candidates who could succeed me in managing investments. All of them have experience managing substantial sums of money and have expressed a strong interest in joining Berkshire. The board is well aware of their strengths, so we're in good shape if the need for a transition arises.
What happened in 1994 regarding the Financial Accounting Standards Board and stock options?

Well, in 1994, the U.S. Senate voted 88-9 to tell the Financial Accounting Standards Board to back off from its plan to make companies record the value of stock options as an expense. The FASB had initially decided that stock options were a form of compensation and should be expensed, but after the Senate's vote, they changed their tune and gave companies a choice: they could either expense the value of the options or ignore the expense if the options were issued at market value.
How did CEOs of S&P 500 companies react to the new accounting guidelines for stock options?

Let's just say they took the low road. Out of the 500 companies in the S&P, only two chose to expense the value of their stock options. The rest decided to ignore the expense, which allowed them to report higher earnings. I think it's pretty clear that many CEOs were more interested in padding their bottom line - and maybe even justifying their own big stock option grants - than in giving investors an honest picture of their company's financials.
What annual return do the equities in the fund need to earn for the fund to achieve an overall return of 8%?
The equities need to earn 9.2% annually for the fund to achieve that 8% overall return, and that's after all fees, which are now higher than they've ever been.
How much would the Dow need to gain by the end of this century to match the 5.3% annual market-value gain of the last century?

To match that 5.3% annual gain, the Dow would need to close at about 2,000,000 on December 31, 2099. That's a staggering number, and it puts into perspective the hype around the Dow crossing certain thresholds – we've got a long way to go.
You mention that commentators hyperventilate when the Dow crosses an even number of thousands. Do you think this reaction is justified, given the historical performance of the market?

I don't think so. A 5.3% annual gain for the century is a reasonable expectation, but it's not something to get overly excited about. As I said, if they keep reacting that way, they'll have a lot of seizures over the next 92 years - 1,986 to be exact. It's just not a likely outcome that the market will be that volatile.
You discuss the role of 'helpers' in the investment process, such as consultants and high-priced managers. How do you think their involvement affects the average investor's returns?

Well, I think it's simple math. The helper-aided group, as a whole, must be below average because they incur high costs that diminish their returns. Meanwhile, the passive and index investors, who don't have those high costs, will earn the average return minus very low costs. That means the passive group will come out on top, not because they're geniuses, but because they're not paying all those extra fees.
Why do CEOs opt for high investment assumptions in their reporting?

I believe CEOs opt for high investment assumptions because it allows them to report higher earnings. It's a way for them to look good in the short term, even if it's not entirely realistic. And if they're wrong, the consequences won't come back to haunt them until long after they're gone.
What's the problem with public pension promises in the United States?

The problem with public pension promises is that they're huge and often woefully underfunded. Politicians make promises that are easy to keep in the short term, like early retirement and generous cost-of-living adjustments, but they'll be very difficult to keep in the long term, especially with people living longer and inflation being a certainty.
How do you estimate loss reserves for Berkshire's insurance units, and what challenges do you face in making these estimates accurate?

Well, we do our best to make these guesses accurate by putting a dollar value on each known loss event, including associated costs like attorney's fees. However, it's a tough task because we're dealing with a huge number of events, some of which we haven't even heard about yet, and payments can stretch out for 50 years or more. It's a bit like trying to predict the weather decades in advance.
Can you give an example of a situation where it might take a long time to discover a loss, and how that affects your estimation process?

Think of an embezzlement that remains undiscovered for years. We have to include a large reserve for losses like that, which we haven't yet heard about. It's a challenge because we can't just wait for all the facts to come in - we have to make an educated guess based on our experience and data. And sometimes, we'll hear about losses from policies that covered our insured many decades ago, which just adds to the complexity.
What kind of challenge do you face in estimating loss liability at your insurance companies?

We face the challenge of dealing with what I call 'rented suits' - old policies from many decades ago where we can't accurately estimate the total cost. It's like trying to predict the total bill for a funeral without knowing all the expenses upfront. We make our best guess, but even that's subject to surprises down the line.
Do you think your current reserves are adequate to cover these potential losses?

Personally, I believe our stated reserves are adequate, but I've been wrong before. It's a tough prediction to make, and we won't really know how accurate our guesses are until 10 or 20 years from now.
